pkg/config/config.go.message: I don't think these are needed anymore.

These functions are basically identical, and I have a feeling we're going to be adding more similar functions. Maybe it makes sense to write a generic function that takes a map[string]interface{} and returns a sorted []string?
Disregard this - such a  function isn't realistically possible in Go

Can we create a typed error for this? Something like ErrMissingConfig. It could sit next to this error:
https://opendev.org/airship/airshipctl/src/branch/master/pkg/errors/common.go#L12

We could reuse that error in GetClusters

Does this function need to return the context passed into it? That's usually only done for function chaining, which can't be done with multiple return values.
This bubbles up to AddContext as well.

Does this function need to return an error? It doesn't look like that's possible right now.

I don't know if this function should have this many return values. It looks like it might create a lot of "dogsledding", like in the following
ctx, _, _, _, err := c.GetCurrentContext("foo")

I think it might be better to return (*Context, error), and then create separate functions for the other config objects. For example
GetClusterFromContext(ctx *Context) (*Cluster)
Changed to many func each returning a single object
above this variable is kcontext please standardize

templates/yum_update.sh.j2.message: this j2 var is set the same way but as the pkg_mgr fact, like here: https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image/src/branch/master/tasks/yum_update_buildah.yml#L26

> this j2 var is set the same way but as the pkg_mgr fact, like here:
 > https://opendev.org/openstack/ansible-role-tripleo-modify-image/src/branch/master/tasks/yum_update_buildah.yml#L26

That sets it too early. When I run this from a RHEL8 host, it sets the variable to dnf as expected, but then the yum_update.sh file is mounted as a volume into the RHEL7 containers and run independently - that's when the script should figure out whether to use dnf or yum.

I don't think it's as complicated as the facts cache during upgrade.
oh, I think the real issue may be related to the facts cache issues in the upgrade process? https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698891/

specs/centos8-migration.rst.message:
It's even more than that. tgtd is no longer given to us. It was in C7 only because of EPEL. It's not there for C8 though. Moreover, we are overally dropping EPEL because it often violates packaging quality.

This affects LVM backend which exports itself via either tgtd or LIO. We still need to support tgtd on Ubuntu&Debian where it is not going anywhere.

Initiator does not (need to) change (except due to the image update of course) so hardware-based iscsi is not affected (iscsi backend outside lvm).

specs/centos8.rst.message: Piliszek :-) The "sz" is pronounced like "sh" in case pronunciation makes you remember it. ;-)
Apologies! I know you also have a funny slash on your l. Hopefully omitting it doesn't completely change your name.
It changes pronunciation but otherwise makes my name outside of ASCII. I share this trait with Michał. ;-) Marcin is lucky here.

ansible/group_vars/all.yml.message: Since tgt is definitely *not* the way of the future, could we change the default for other distros as well? Or at least notify and change in V.
We can't change the default and not affect existing installs though.
I mean new deployments so that people finally stop using tgt. :-)
The migration is difficult though, which is why this never got merged until c8 came along.
Yeah, that's why I retreated to notification and later change. We can't block on all things "people won't read".

I think it is the generic fixtures.fixture.Fixture.cleanUp() that runs for every functional test fixture tearing down nova dependencies like the DB that causes the excessive runtime as it makes the parallel running migration to hit the db that is down, producing such logs:

"The services table record for the nova-conductor service on host conductor is gone."
http://paste.openstack.org/show/788119/
OK, if that's what's causing that error it shows up in a lot of tests from what I've seen, so we might have more than just this one. Nice catch though.

neutron_tempest_plugin/scenario/test_dns.message: Meh, this is lacking "found=False", so it actually verifies that record deletion still isn't working as it should ... :-(

In the interest of full disclosure: Using 12345 here is a bit of a hack, devstack currently hardcodes the tenant range to 1-1000, for the scenario to work, we will need to use any ID that's outside of that range. So the test could fail against deployments where 12345 is configured as valid vxlan ID for tenants. One could add code that looks at the configuration and dynamically determines a proper ID to use, but I decided that the added complexity wasn't worth the effort.

No, the IDs that are assigned automatically are those that will be filtered out by this check https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/plugins/ml2/extensions/dns_integration.py#L337-L351 , resulting in no DNS records being published for them. One could copy that code in this test in order to programatically determine an ID that would be useable, if you think that that would be preferable.

If You would duplicate this code here and try to detect what segmentation id would be used, it would also require to have some config option in tempest to specify range used in neutron, right?
In that case, easier would be to just propose config option with segmentation_id which should be used here and avoid this extra logic here :)
But for now, IMO let's keep it as it is now. Maybe You can just add small comment why it is like that.
Do we really need to specify that? Can't it be choosen automatically?
can You remove this commented line maybe?
Oops, leftover from testing. I had considered whether to test with v6 addresses here, too, but they shouldn't behave differently in this scenario.
smart way to get IPv4 and IPv6 addresses :)
Glad you like it, I don't think it's rather elegant, but it does seem to work.
This actually relates to the comment I made here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662409/38/neutron/plugins/ml2/extensions/dns_integration.py@438. Here we are testing that change in behavior

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: We need a unit test for this. Also, surely we have constants somewhere for s390 and s390x? Can you use them if we do? Don't worry about it if not

But it does - you just need version 5.9.0, as you commented in the commit message. Could you modify this to include a version check? If we don't have the correct version and are using one of these architectures then we should skip. Otherwise, we shouldn't.

You could simplify this a bit by

 if cpu.arch in (arch.S390X, arch.S390) and
And I think this line should be indented one more time to not align with L8269. Also, I think you'll need another set of parentheses around L8267-L8268 for line continuation.
you are right, I will update it, thanks

You need to put this whole if statement inside parentheses to pass pep8 for continuing a line:

 if (cpu.arch in (arch.S390X, arch.S390) and
         not self._host.has_min_version(min_libvirt_version)):
This line needs to be indented once more to pass pep8.
These 3 lines need to be unindented once to pass pep8.

src/README.md.message:
This charm can optionally dedicate a provider's physical
network to serving Ganesha NFS shares. It does so through its support for Juju spaces.
<blank line>
The space name is hardcoded to `tenant-storage` and should be accessible to those tenants...
It's not really "hardcoded", the admin just has to tell Juju what space maps to the "tenant-storage" space defined in the charm's metadata.
I'm trying to get everyone to use indentation (of four spaces) to achieve code blocks in MD files. Please try and then confirm it renders correctly.

The charm uses a space called `tenant-storage` and it should be accessible [sic]...

Also, please keep line length to a max of 79 columns/characters.

does this need and explicit mapping to the provide network as well? i.e.:

  --provider-physical-network physnet1

that might be implicit if there is only a single one defined in the charm configuration.

I think it would be good to document the MAAS side of this setup as well.

MAAS needs to not provide DHCP services, and should use a network range for allocations which does not overlap with the Neutron configuration.

I guess it's still OK for neutron to setup DHCP services as it will ignore any DHCP requests for things it does not know about.

heat/engine/clients/os/vitrage.py.message: Agree with Rico that you definitely want to implement is_not_found().

Like this:

  def is_not_found(self, exc):
    return isinstance(exc, vitrageclient.exceptions.ClientException) and exc.code == 404

It doesn't appear true that you can't get a 404 when deleting a template: https://opendev.org/openstack/vitrage/src/branch/master/vitrage/api/controllers/v1/template.py#L107

However, as you said, that doesn't actually happen when the template is not found: https://opendev.org/openstack/vitrage/src/branch/master/vitrage/api_handler/apis/template.py#L98-L99

In fact, looking through that first file, it appears that literally every type of error returns a 404, almost all of which are completely the wrong code. So I guess it is indeed safer not to implement this.
I don't see how this can be implemented at this stage, since vitrage template delete does not return any indication that the resource is not found

expected a list for dictionary value @ data['templates']
I didn't add these two jobs because I'm not sure if we still need to run them. But will be fine to add them in if anyone thinks these jobs are useful

Because you need to run tempest + non-tempest tests in this job then, you can drive from 'devstack' job.

With that, you will be able to reuse the existing scripts to run the heat_integration as well as the heat_tempest_plugin tests.

I am writing the idea of playbooks below:

    pre-run: playbooks/pre-heat-tests.yaml
    run: playbooks/run-heat-tests.yaml
    post-run: playbooks/post-heat-tests.yaml

These playbooks can run the new ansible roles something like below:

pre-heat-tests.yaml - this can have role which can run heat_integrationtests/pre_test_hook.sh

run-heat-tests.yaml - this can have role which can run heat_integrationtests/post_test_hook.sh which actually run tests. You can rename this script as name is confusing. It took time for me to actually find this location of tests run :).

playbooks/post-heat-tests.yaml - This does not need as such but you can do post run tasks here. devstack post-run will still be executed before heat playbook if any.

I don't see this anchor referenced elsewhere in this file, so can we delete it?

This is one of the worst 'features' of yaml, so let's avoid if possible :)
should be fine to get rid of this, since roles already defined by *roles*
this is not needed as you will use separate roles to run the tests not the tempest tox env.
Done
this is the default in devstack now so you can remove.
Done
This is the default but I guess it doesn't hurt to be explicit.
It's unfortunate that we now have to keep the tempest config and heat config in sync in separate places, but I can't think of a better way.

What I meant is that in the old way if you wanted to make a legacy job, you only had to set one thing - "disable_convergence: 'true'" on line 43 of the base. But now you have to remember to set two different things (on lines 128 & 132), and if you don't change them both in lockstep then the configuration is invalid.

That's not a big deal, but it also applies to other things in this list of configs (e.g. hidden_stack_tag).

Maybe in future we could change configure_tempest_for_heat to look at the Heat config and configure tempest to match for some of these, rather than need to specify both in the zuul.yaml.
this patch uses the same config place (in tempest.conf) actually, so is that a better way for you?

It could be mildly annoying that to change the skip lists we have to modify the Zuul config, with the result that *every* job (including e.g. requirements) has to be re-run. Could it go in the configure_tempest_for_heat function in the devstack plugin maybe?
Fine to put it configure_tempest_for_heat, so Done
Do you know what's involved in migrating the grenade job away from legacy as well? Would it be easier to do it at the same time?

actually we do not have base zuulv3 job ready for grenade, which should be easy to use in all grenade jobs.
work is under review - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/548936/

> actually we do not have base zuulv3 job ready for grenade, which

 > work is under review - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/548936/

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Current commit message is hard to understand the problem.
It is necessary to include what the original problem is.

Please see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Information_in_commit_messages

 Do not assume the reviewer understands what the original problem was.

 When reading bug reports, after a number of back & forth
 comments, it is often as clear as mud, what the root cause
 problem is. The commit message should have a clear statement
 as to what the original problem is. The bug is merely
 interesting historical background on /how/ the problem was
 identified. It should be possible to review a proposed patch
 for correctness without needing to read the bug ticket.

nova/network/neutronv2/api.py.message: actually we can return at here directly.
indeed, thanks Alex for the suggestion!

Is is possible for more than one port to be associated with an IP address? If so, this would be a changing behavior as previously the last port with a matching IP address would be found, whereas now the first matching port will be returned.

It is technically possible, thats a good point...

Its tempting to raise a different exception for "there is more than one port with that address, so I can't help you"

just clarify, I talk with John at IRC, I get clear what he proposal, he prefer to not change anything.

I'm ok with it. Actually I think both it is ok, I feel vm have to port with same fixed id, and try to attach floating ip is a strange use-case. I didn't few the behaviour change to attach the first port only will break user something. But I'm also ok just keep with current behaviour. When the user try to do that, I guess they just didn't clear what are they doing...
Raise exception instead of just choice one of it, so that sounds like change the API behaviour

I should expand, you have two private networks, they can both have 192.168.0.42 on that network.

Now if you do that and attach them to the same VM, you probably have a world of pain...

it is tempting to raise an exception if you find two ports with the address.
and I suspect the current behavior was not intentional, maybe just something wrong with breaking out the nested loops.

thanks all for the review, but I don't find the difference between the first port and the last port to choose if the instance has more than one port with the same fixed ip address. but if you like to keep the current behavior, I think we should at least leave some comments here for why we need the last port, wdyt?
I think you can do what you've done, and add a note that we're returning the first port because having more than one port with the same ID is silly

It seems the fact is, multiple ports can have identical fixed address from different subnets. If taking that into consideration, we should handle this logical flaw first (that is, return the first or last matched port, log something, or raise an exception). I have filled a bug report https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1778870. You can assign it to yourself if you like.

cliff/commandmanager.py.message: Why use an environment variable to control this? Why not just turn it on all the time?
Thought about as kind of experimental feature, changed.
I don't think we want to print this to stdout. I'm not sure we want to output a message like this at all, but if we do it should go to stderr.

Changed to stderr. I would like to have that message it's critical to understand why your partial name does not work
and how your partial name should be modified.

I think we want to move lines 113-118 down here somewhere as an alternative to this if conditional. That lets this existing code handle the exact match, and treats the abbreviations as a fallback. We can then safely ignore a failure of the abbreviations to resolve to exactly 1 command, and the existing handling for unknown commands will work properly.
Please rename this to add a _ to the front of the name to indicate that it is a private function that should not be used outside of cliff.
Please limit each patch to the changes needed to implement it. I don't mind the refactoring in general, but it makes it more confusing to review.
We already have some logic to try to offer suggestions for names that should be triggered by the exception raised when no command is found. So please remove the print.

self._wait_for_migration_status(server, ['finished'])

devstack/files/hooks/qemu.py.message: can't we just drop compatibility with Python 2.x ?

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

devstack/files/hooks/qemu.py.message: We can drop it. We dropped six out which horribly broke master branch users of py2.
*sigh* we are still supporting both version in the downstream, but the wheel is unstoppable.
I am not quite sure it can be dropped, at least the shebang points to the default interpreter which is python2 in current distributions.

python3 doesn't have -t option from the man page, though it doesn't complain if supplied with -t.
I feel it's an ignored argument so removed here, but correct me if I am wrong.
in Python 3.x the -t option is ignored as it disallows mixing spaces and tabs for indentation, so should be good like this.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Thank you - seems thanks to some changes on Sphinx with gettext handler

I would go check whether this runs py2 or py3, but zuul.o.o/jobs crashes my computer :(  Will wait for zuul results instead.

[Later] Hm, actually, I think this job is unused (at least from within this project). There's a *template* of the same name defined on L156 which runs the py36-tips job below.

Anyway, cleaning this up could be done in a separate patch.

I *think* since [1] has merged, this is unnecessary.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/649097/
I think this can go away...
Yes, it can, and would get rid of the py27 unit test job.
...and this should change to ussuri...
...and this should go away.
I can't get to the logs for this, but it *should* now be using py3 by default...
...which means we ought to be able to get rid of this.

This (resulting in job openstackclient-check-plugins) is still running py2. That will need to be fixed in the openstack/openstackclient project where the template & job reside. So we should either propose that patch and make this one depend on it, or call it out as an exception in the commit message ("Note that the openstackclient-check-plugins job will continue to run under py2 until ...")

If it were voting I would insist on the former, but since it's not, meh.
This is still an issue in PS5
Still need to nix this...

...and change this to ussuri.

That should make pep8 run under py3 and get rid of the openstack-tox-py27 job.
I'm pretty sure this is where tempest-full is coming from, and the next line is getting us tempest-full-py3, so this one should go away.
this is redundant and should be removed.
See PS4 comment here
Sorry I'm not sure to understand what I need to do for that.

This is still resulting in running py27 unit tests. Remove this line.
confirmed this ran under py36 ✔

tox.ini.message:
We ought to move this up into [testenv], no?

(And remove it from all the other envs below.)
I think you missed to move the `basepython = python3` in this section, like Eric has suggested.

Yeah, I'm not sure whether that's necessary or not.

I suspect what happens is dependent on where you happen to be running tox. So yeah, probably better to be explicit, if what we're trying to do is stop using py2.

You should move this here so it's inherited by all the blocks:

basepython = python3
We just want to make sure the tox environment things run under uses python3, like the gate jobs will.
My question is it really required to have it? We remove python 2 support, so for me it's useless

It's not useless for me. My dev box (which is where I run tox, many many times per day) is bionic, and uses py2 by default when you say "python". So without this line, I'm running those envs under py2.

And I'm not the only one.

The point of tox (one of them) is so I can vet changes locally before expending gate resources on them. So having py3 be explicit here is important IMHO.

We should add ignore_basepython_conflict here, like [1]. But that's latent and can be done separately.

[Later] Whoops, no, we have to do it now, it's resulting in skipping suites like pep8 [2] and docs [3] (I think that's the cause anyway).

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/a1b0c8b814dc00dd6f5ff0824139584c7e866838/tox.ini#L4-L7
[2] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/b9e4c36e7c2b4c3b833b557705070779/log/job-output.txt#459-461
[3] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/989ff67dbc24431b991b4608a91a6e5d/log/job-output.txt#461-463
nit: ignore_basepython_conflict was introduced in tox 3.1.0, so this needs to be updated.
